titleStmt.title: Three-center feasibility of lung clearance index in infants and preschool children with cystic fibrosis and other lung diseases

analytic.title: Three-center feasibility of lung clearance index in infants and preschool children with cystic fibrosis and other lung diseases

biblStruct.note: Received 15 May 2017; revised 28 July 2017; accepted 1 August 2017

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: Background: Lung clearance index (LCI) detects early ventilation inhomogeneity and has been suggested as sensitive endpoint in multicenter intervention trials in infants and preschoolers with cystic fibrosis (CF).
However, the feasibility of multicenter LCI in this age group has not been determined.
We, therefore, investigated the feasibility of LCI in infants and preschoolers with and without CF in a three-center setting.

Methods: Following central training, standardized SF 6 -MBW measurements were performed in 73 sedated children (10 controls, 49 with CF and 14 with other lung diseases), mean age 2.3 ± 1.2 years across three centers, and data were analyzed centrally.
Results: Overall success rate of LCI measurements was 91.8% ranging from 78.9% to 100% across study sites.
LCI was increased in patients with CF (P b 0.05) and with other lung diseases (P b 0.05) compared to controls.
Conclusion: Our results support feasibility of LCI as multicenter endpoint in clinical trials in infants and preschoolers with CF.

Early onset and progression of lung disease starting in the first months of life remains the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in patients with cystic fibrosis (CF) suggesting that early therapeutic intervention may be most beneficial [1,2].

Therefore, quantitative non-invasive endpoints sensitive to detect early lung abnormalities and disease progression in multicenter studies are warranted for clinical testing of preventive therapies in infants and preschool children with CF [3].

In addition to work focusing on infant pulmonary function tests (PFT) and imaging by chest CT and MRI as outcome measures in this age group [4][5][6][7][8], emerging evidence suggests that lung clearance index (LCI) derived from multiple-breath washout (MBW) may be a suitable outcome measure for this purpose.

First, a series of single center studies demonstrated that LCI detects ventilation inhomogeneity and response to therapeutic interventions such as inhaled hypertonic saline and Dornase alpha in school age children with normal spirometry, as well as preschool children and infants with CF [5,[9][10][11][12][13][14][15].
Further, LCI has been used in observational studies across two sites by the Australian Respiratory Early Surveillance Team for Cystic Fibrosis (AREST CF) [16].

Recently, LCI was shown to be feasible and sensitive to detect disease progression in preschool children with CF and response to CFTR modulator therapy in school age children with CF in multicenter trials [17][18][19].
However, data on multicenter feasibility of MBW in infants and preschool children with CF including study centers naïve to this technique is lacking.

Further, in contrast to older children where MBW can be performed without sedation by inhalation of 100% oxygen to washout nitrogen (N 2 ) from the lungs, measurements in infants and young preschool children require sedation to ensure cooperativity and the use of tracer gases such as sulfur hexafluoride (SF 6 ) to avoid alterations of the breathing pattern induced by exposure to pure oxygen in this age group [20].
These factors make LCI measurements in infants and young preschool children more demanding and may hamper the feasibility of multicenter trials.

The aim of this study was, therefore, to implement and validate a standardized multicenter SF 6 MBW protocol in sedated infants and preschool children and determine the feasibility of LCI as an outcome measure of early CF lung disease in the clinical trial network of the German Center for Lung Research (DZL) in preparation of an early intervention trial in this age group (ClinicalTrials.gov
Identifier: NCT01619657).

We conducted central and local training of the study site members and measurements were performed in infants and preschool children with CF, healthy controls and age-matched children with other lung diseases following a standardized MBW protocol under supervision of the central MBW lab with central data analysis and prompt feedback for troubleshooting.
Results on feasibility of successful MBW measurements and LCI values were compared between the participating centers and study groups.

This prospective multicenter validation study was coordinated by the Translational Lung Research Center Heidelberg (TLRC) and conducted across 3 sites of the DZL, a multi-site national research center established to develop new approaches for prevention, diagnosis and therapy of severe lung diseases including CF [21].
The study was approved by the Ethics Committee of the University Hospital Heidelberg (coordinating center) and the local Ethics Committees of all participating sites.
Parents obtained detailed information on the study protocol including sedation and gave their signed informed consent.

In total, 73 infants and preschool children (mean age 2.3 ± 1.2 years; range 0.0-5.1 years), including 49 patients with CF, 14 patients with other lung diseases and 10 healthy controls were prospectively recruited.

The group of patients with other lung diseases included primary ciliary dyskinesia (n = 1), hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (n = 1), chronic kidney disease stage 5 with recurrent respiratory infections (n = 2), immunodeficiency (n = 2), bronchiolitis obliterans (n = 1), recurrent obstructive bronchitis (n = 2), status post pneumonia (n = 1), status post pneumothorax (n = 1), congenital pulmonary airway malformation (n = 1), prematurity (n = 1), and hypoplasia of right upper lobe (n = 1).
Demographics of the study population are summarized in Table 1.
Z-scores for weight, height and BMI were derived from reference values of healthy children in Germany [22,23].

Details on CFTR genotypes of patients with CF, diagnoses in patients with other lung diseases, and information on indications for sedation and how lung disease was excluded in the healthy control group are available in the online supplement.
MBW measurements were established at TLRC before the start of this study [11].
At the Airway Research Center North (ARCN) and the Universities of Giessen and Marburg Lung Center (UGMLC), MBW measurements in infants were established during this study.

Children were sedated with oral or rectal chloral hydrate (100 mg/kg body weight, maximum dose of 2 g) as per guidelines [24,25] and MBW testing was performed using the infant setup of a commercially available mainstream ultrasonic flowmeter (Exhalyzer D, Eco Medics, Duernten, Switzerland) with SF 6 as tracer gas and the child lying in supine position as previously described [9,10,26].
Details on performance of MBW are provided in the online supplement.
Abnormal LCI was defined as above 7.4, the upper limit of normal (ULN) from previously investigated non-CF controls without lung disease [11].
A successful investigation was defined as any MBW measurement with two or more technically acceptable washout curves in the set [27].

The following requirements were pre-specified and had to be fulfilled by DZL sites prior to inclusion in the study: i) availability of an Exhalyzer D (Eco Medics, Duernten, Switzerland) with infant set up, ii) availability of the tracer gas mixture with 4% SF 6 , and iii) routine sedation with chloral hydrate for diagnostic procedures.

The CF centers at the five DZL sites were invited to submit feasibility questionnaires for the evaluation of these prespecified criteria and technical specifications of MBW hardware and software versions installed.
Specifications were reviewed within 4 weeks and three DZL sites including the ARCN, the TLRC and the UGMLC fulfilled all criteria and were selected as study sites.

Following this selection process, a datasheet containing the standardized MBW protocol and the data acquisition and analysis software version installed at the coordinating center in Heidelberg (WBreath version 2.0.0.0, ndd Medical Technologies, Zurich, Switzerland) were distributed and the study team at each site was instructed to install this software version on their MBW PC.
Prior to the start of the study, a dedicated training session on acquisition of the MBW study protocol and on systematic washout interpretation was held at the coordinating site at Heidelberg.
Members of all participating sites attended this teaching session.

div.head: Implementation of the MBW protocol at study sites

p.s: Initiation of each study site was individually supported by the coordinating center by a team of three experts (MS, CJ, SYG).

Initiation visits were held at each site and all personnel (lung function technicians, pediatricians, study nurses) involved in the study were trained with regard to the standard operating procedure (SOP) of MBW protocol including calibration of the MBW machine, performing standardized MBW measurements in infants and preschool children, as well as organizational procedures and management of acquired data such as pseudonymization and transfer of MBW files for central evaluation to the coordinating center.
The previously installed MBW software was checked, corrections were made as necessary and a supervised MBW measurement was carried out on site to ensure standardized execution and quality.
A pediatrician trained in MBW performance and analysis at the respective study site evaluated the MBW tracings diagnostically and reported findings to the parents.
MBW files were pseudonymized and sent to the coordinating center for central quality control, evaluation and statistical analysis.
Reports of central analyses were fed back to the study sites to improve their experience in interpretation of diagnostic MBW measurements.
MBW data were analyzed by an experienced reader (MS) specialized in pediatric lung function testing with the same software version.
For analysis of LCI, only results of children with at least two successful washout curves fulfilling quality criteria were used [27].
Files were corrected following a previously described new algorithm [28,29].
Data were analyzed using SPSS version 21.0 (SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL, USA) and are shown as mean ± SD or percentage, if not indicated otherwise.
For categorical data, groups were compared with Fisher's exact test and for continuous data with unpaired Student's t-test or ANOVA and post-hoc Bonferroni test.
Associations between LCI, age and anthropometric values were assessed by scatter plot and linear regression with determination of the Pearson correlation coefficient [30].
A P value of b 0.05 was accepted to indicate statistical significance.

div.head: Feasibility of three-center LCI in infants and preschool children

p.s: To determine the feasibility of three-center LCI, we performed MBW measurements in a total of 73 sedated infants and preschool children (Table 1) across three sites of the DZL (ARCN, TLRC and UGMLC).
Demographics of the three study groups were similar except a lower BMI z-score in CF patients compared to controls (Table 1).
Multicenter MBW measurements were performed according to a standardized protocol using SF 6 as tracer gas in supine position with a face mask as interface.
Sedation with chloral hydrate was successful in all children without adverse effects (Fig. 1).
At TLRC where SF 6 -MBW was implemented in this age group prior to this study [11,12], all attempts were successful (Fig. 1).
At ARCN and UGMLC, where MBW in infants and preschool children was implemented during this study, overall success rates were 78.9% and 87.5%, respectively (Fig. 1).

The success rates at these two sites previously naïve to SF 6 -MBW in this age group were higher than results obtained in a prior single center implementation study at TLRC with an overall success rate of 67.5% [11].
Overall, multicenter MBW investigations in the present study were successful in 67 of 73 infants and preschool children resulting in a success rate of 91.8% (Fig. 1).

Comparison of the total number of MBW attempts across study sites and study groups revealed no differences except a lower number of attempts in infants and preschool children with other lung diseases at ARCN compared to TLRC (Table 2).
The number of successful attempts was lower at ARCN compared to TLRC in patients with CF and with other lung diseases (Table 2).
On average, across all study sites and study groups, 3.4 attempts were performed to gain at least two washout curves per child fulfilling quality criteria (Table 2).
Overall, more attempts were performed in children with CF (3.6 ± 1.2) compared to the control group (3.1 ± 0.3; P b 0.05) or patients with other lung diseases (3.0 ± 0.6; P b 0.01).
However, this higher number of attempts was not always necessary to obtain two successful measurements and was mainly performed for training purposes in this implementation study.
The reasons for unsuccessful MBW investigations (b 2 washout curves fulfilling quality criteria) in our study were recurrent sighs (n = 3 children) and technical problems (n = 3 children).

In some infants and preschool children, at least two washout curves fulfilled quality criteria thus qualifying as successful investigation, but further MBW measurements of the same set did not meet acceptability criteria due to i) differences in FRC and/or LCI N 10% (in 3 or more traces) or 5% (in 2 traces) (n = 8 children), ii) recurrent sighs (n = 2 children), iii) leaks (n = 1 child) and technical problems (n = 1 child).
At least one acceptable washout curve was obtained in 93.2% (Table 2).

div.head: Three-center LCI in infants and preschool children with CF, other lung diseases and controls

p.s: The mean absolute LCI in infants and preschool children of the control group was 6.6 ± 0.4 (Fig. 2).
In the CF group, the mean LCI was significantly increased to 7.3 ± 1.2 (P b 0.05) (Fig. 2).
The mean LCI was also elevated in infants and preschool children with other lung diseases (7.2 ± 1.0; P b 0.05 vs. controls) (Fig. 2).
Across all three study sites, 10 out of 43 (23.3%)
patients with CF with successful MBW measurements had an elevated LCI above 7.4, the ULN determined from a previous control group (Table 3) [11].

In infants and preschool children with other lung diseases, 4 out of 14 (28.6%) had an elevated LCI, whereas the remaining study population with successful MBW measurements including 33 CF patients, 10 patients with other lung diseases and all controls had a LCI below the ULN.
In all three groups (controls, CF, other lung diseases), the LCI did not correlate with age, gender, anthropometric values, or clinical symptoms such as cough.

Comparison of LCI data from infants and preschool children with CF obtained at individual study sites revealed no differences in the mean LCI (P = 0.287), coefficients of variation of the LCI (P = 0.689) or the frequency of patients with elevated LCI (P = 0.645) between the three study centers (Table 3).

In contrast to other organs such as the pancreas, the lungs are structurally normal at birth in children with CF and early diagnosis by newborn screening has created a unique opportunity for early therapeutic intervention that may delay or ultimately prevent the onset of irreversible lung damage [8,31,32].

Therefore, clinical trials testing this early intervention paradigm and outcome measures that are feasible and sensitive to detect early lung disease in infants and preschool children with CF in a multicenter setting are urgently needed.

In this context, previous studies focused on infant PFT and imaging by chest CT and MRI and the strengths and limitations of these techniques as outcome measures of lung disease in young children with CF were recently discussed elsewhere [4][5][6][7][8].
This study demonstrates for the first time that multicenter SF 6 -MBW is feasible in sedated infants and preschool children with CF and other lung diseases with high success rates.

Further, we show that the frequency and range of early ventilation inhomogeneity detected by multicenter LCI is comparable to previous single center studies in infants and preschool children with CF [9][10][11].

In addition, our study demonstrates that multicenter LCI can be established successfully in a clinical trial network containing study sites without prior experience in MBW in this challenging age group.

Collectively, these results support LCI as a promising non-invasive quantitative outcome measure for monitoring of early ventilation inhomogeneity in multicenter observational studies and as an endpoint in early intervention trials in infants and preschool children with CF.

Using an approach of central training, implementation of standard operating procedures and harmonized MBW protocols, continuous supervision and central MBW analysis to transfer methodology from a center with prior expertise in SF 6 -MBW in sedated infants and preschool children [11,12] to study sites previously naïve to the technique, yielded high rates of technically acceptable MBW investigations across study groups (100% in controls; 87.8% in CF; 100% in other lung diseases) and study sites (78.9% at ARCN; 100% at TLRC; 87.5% at UGMLC) with an overall success rate of 91.8% (Fig. 1; Table 2).
Of note these results are comparable to the feasibility of the raised-volume rapid thoracic compression (RVRTC) technique in sedated infants [33].

The two main factors contributing to unsuccessful MBW measurements in our study were i) technical problems with the Exhalyzer D not related to errors in calibration or performance of MBW; and ii) exchange of the investigator performing MBW with a new learning curve.
The latter observation indicates that, besides teaching and supervision, constancy of the study team is an important factor contributing to sustained success rates.

Compared to our results obtained in sedation, a recent study in unsedated preschool children demonstrated that success rates of MBW measurements were highly age-dependent and substantially lower (0-33%) in unsedated children under the age of 3 years [34].
This highlights the prerequisite of sedation to ensure feasibility of MBW measurements with success rates that are adequate and required for endpoints in clinical trials in this age group.
This study also has limitations.

Regarding the transferability of the high MBW success rates obtained in our study, it has to be noted that the DZL is a highly competent translational research network well equipped with experienced study site personnel.
This established infrastructure may have an important impact on feasibility and transferability of our results to a broader multicenter clinical trial setting.

Therefore, replication studies in larger networks, such as the ECFS-Clinical Trial Network or the CF Therapeutics Development Network will be necessary prior to using LCI as an outcome measure in multicenter clinical trials in infants and preschool children.

Ideally, these studies should also include longitudinal MBW measurements capturing the time points typically included in phase 3 clinical trials, i.e. at baseline, 1 month, 6 months and 12 months apart.
Another limitation of our study is the use of SF 6 as a tracer gas that is not available in all countries due to its classification as a greenhouse gas.
However, inhalation of pure oxygen that is required for nitrogen washout as an alternative to SF 6 induces altered breathing patterns in infants and at present, this issue remains unsolved [26,35].

Refined MBW protocols using either reduced SF 6 concentrations, alternative tracer gases or N 2 -MBW measurements with a priming phase to avoid abnormal breathing in infants are currently tested and may solve this problem in the future.

In addition to limitations with availability of SF 6 as a tracer gas, chloral hydrate is not available in all countries for sedation of infants hampering applicability of the operating procedure validated in our study in such countries.

In summary, our study demonstrates that assessment of lung function by MBW is feasible with high success rates in sedated infants and preschool children with CF, other lung diseases and pulmonary healthy controls with a commercially available mainstream ultrasonic flowmeter.

Further, this study shows that the LCI is sensitive to detect abnormalities of lung function in infants and preschool children with CF and other lung diseases in a multicenter setting following initial training and supervision by a specialized pediatric lung function laboratory.

These results support the use of LCI not only for diagnostic monitoring of early lung disease, but as a potential non-invasive endpoint in early intervention clinical trials in patients with CF and possibly other genetic or acquired early onset lung diseases in a multicenter setting.

Fig. 2. Summary of multicenter lung clearance index (LCI) in infants and preschool children without lung disease (control), with CF and with other lung diseases.
Dotted line represents upper limit of normal (ULN) of 7.4.

Open circles (ARCN, CF Center at Airway Research Center North), closed circles (TLRC, CF Center at Translational Lung Research Center Heidelberg) and triangles (UGMLC, CF Center at Universities of Giessen and Marburg Lung Center) represent data from individual children from the respective study site, horizontal lines represent mean values for each group.
*P b 0.05 vs. control group.

The authors thank the children and their families for their participation in the study.

This work was supported in part by the German Ministry for Education and Research (82DZL00401, 82DZL0040A1, 82DZL10106, 82DZL10501), the German Cystic Fibrosis Association Mukoviszidose e.V. (grant 15/01), the Dietmar Hopp Foundation and the Mukoviszidose Förderverein Giessen e.V.
The funders had no role in study design, data collection and analysis, decision to publish, or preparation of the manuscript.

Conception and design of the study: MS, MVK, LN, MAM; Acquisition, analysis and interpretation of data: MS, SYG, CJ, SB, IR, GD, MVK, LN, MAM; Drafting the article or revising it critically for important intellectual content: MS, SYG, CJ, SB, IR, GD, MVK, LN, MAM.
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jcf.2017.08.001.
